threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

It's all about the platforming, exploration, and treasure hunting, you CAN take unlimited hits but you end up paying for it in the literal sense, with how you need to spend cash to unlock the final bonus dungeon, as well as affecting your endings (which are multiples, each with their own path of levels). The status effect abilities are also fun and novel.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: It’s far better than you think
threads.com:
Behold, the Bandai wonderswan. The superior 90s handheld that deserves far more credit than it receives

With a library matching the Dreamcast in number and variety, it’s 200 games cover genres that portable gaming frankly sucked at beforehand.

Here you’ll find some of the best strategy RPGs and fighters handhelds ever had to offer in 99.

Backed by the powerhouse that was square, the console got a lot of big name titles from the developer. Final fantasies, mystery dungeons, and a fucking clock tower- the selection of quality RPGs on the console kicks the shit out of what the gameboy color and NGPC was offering that same year.

Being the first handheld with a widescreen, it made real nice for fighting games and vertical puzzlers.

From pocket fighter to guilty gear, to digimon and one piece, the system has a healthy selection of fun brawlers that play very well on the small screen.

On the note of one piece, the console was notable for its anime tie ins. Bandai was a licensing powerhouse after all.

The system was quite capable too! Handily shitting all over the cpus of the gameboy and neo geo pocket- this was the only system of the 3 that could run a full ass web browser.

Nearly the entire library runs at 75 fps. Why? Idk but it’s quite nice. Games are smooth with lots of animation and fast clean scrolling. Hundreds of sprites dotting the screen without hiccup.
The system is no slouch in audio hardware either. Having a capable synth setup, AND cool ass sample capabilities- it has a sound that when used to full potential reminds me of some neo geo titles.

Despite the device being a properly capable 16 bit handheld for the time, the thing SIPS power. A single AA battery will keep the thing in active gameplay for well over 40 hours. That’s not 40 hours standby- that’s 40 hours of straight gameplay. On ONE battery. Gbc could barely muster 10 on 2 of the things.
This was also a console that only cost about $30 on release.

>>9439102
How do you qualify "good melody" and does good melody alone account for a soundtrack's creative value? Sure S1 has a lot of melodies (be it due to Copeland's fancy of that blues rock prog jam stuff) but while maintaining consistent production quality all the way through, the stylistic range in the game's scope isn't very broad.

S2 saw the major use of digital sound design and atmospheric sampling, at least the former of which S3 took even further; things either nonexistent or so sparse in S1's soundtrack it's a burden to find examples. I could only find one clear instance of the latter Ice Cavern. Do the howls in Beast Makers count? Tell me if you can find more. For me the expansion of sound design beyond mere mallets, guitar and organ (and loud as fuck bass) adds fresh variety and is an argument in favor of increased creativity, not the lack of it.

Save for Greatest Hits wildcards, every track in S23 clearly corresponds to that respective level's theme. An anecdote from Copeland himself about Spyro 1:
>By the way, all the careful work I did in matching certain tracks to particular levels went unused. I’m not sure if they were just unaware that I matched levels with tracks, or that they just made different creative choices, but the result seemed kind of random to me.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I've taken the LCD pill since 2014. I'm not blessed with a large house, neither I have the skills to so technical maintenance, so selling my CRT and four consoles, then moving on to emulation seemed better to me. In fact, I still think I made the better choice for my case, but I won't lie about LCD's response time: the average ones plain suck.

I'm not talking about latency, I've reached a point in which input lag is negligible to me, I'm talking about, in general terms, "motion clarity". Take picrel for an example. Even as a kid, I had no problem with that kind of bonua room in Donkey Kong Country. If you paid attention, you could clearly see the last barrel where the item hid itself in. With your average LCD screen, there's always some ghosting the nearby barrels, so it's very hard to be sure. Granted, this is an fringe case, and most of time the player will be fine, though I'm pretty bummed LCD screens seem to be stuck with bad response times for years now.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: When I was a kid I loved dragon warrior for NES. Now as an adult I want to make my own RPG in the spirit of dragon warrior but with more modern story telling. Do you think a game like that would have an audience today? Of course, the graphics would be "shit" but I would focus more on the story and gameplay.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
When I was a kid, we had dreams of the future when it came to video games. We'd always speculate about how advanced video games would be in the future. Would they all be 3D? Would virtual reality be a thing? Would they be indistinguishable from cartoons?

New video games were engrossing, because they were slowly inching toward those goals. They'd constantly push and question what a video game "should" look like.Even NES RPGs were engrossing because of the detailed enemy sprites and gigantic world maps.

I think any game that tries to capture the look of a specific time period is inherently missing the spirit of that time period. Those games aren't being made with the intent to push technology to its limits or try new things. They're empty nostalgia trips that miss what made those games great in the first place.

The audience for old system JRPGs does exist but I doubt it is large. Approach it as a labor of love side project or a learning experience but not as a means of significant income.
>but with more modern story telling.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The problem is exactly that there were too many of those projects, too many programs designed so anyone can make his own RPG, which lead to a pile of mediocre stuff so noone is interested in this anymore.

So you'd really have to make something that stands out or already be someon.

The other issue is that RPGs have for long turned into something for which what matters the most are story and graphics. This can be said for many genres, but more so for RPGs. And the entire point of making an oldschool Famicom style RPG would be an emphasis on gameplay, something the RPG audience does not care for anymore.

I too have a bunch of ideas for a Famicom RPG, and I already am a retro game designer with a foot in the industry, but I doubt I will ever fullfill this RPG idea because it is too risky. But if I had to do it, I would make sure not to use any of the shit "do it yourself" programs peoplel are recommending you, make sure to hire a visual artist that stands out, but only after a market research that tells me if and how I can release it in Japan.

Regardless of whether you think it's a good or bad thing, post games that have a distinctly "modern" feel. Eg, low difficulty, forgiving mechanics, qol features, tight hitboxes. My examples:
>Snes Aladdin
The "parachute" mechanic and the high amount of mid-air control make this game one of the most accessible platformers of the era. The game easily could have been 5x as difficult without them.
>Monster World IV
Asha's sword swings can still hit enemies that overlap her sprite, and her attacks get priority. That plus the wide hitboxes on upward, downward, and sideways air swings make controlling her feel like a modern indie game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9437361
It's not that bad. It's not exactly fantastic combat or anything, but it's easy to learn. As long as you adhere to your tagged skills and didn't spec your character retardedly, the combat will work, your hits will connect and you won't use up your stamina way too fast.

>>9437413
>Using dice rolls in a computer game is hella fuckin retarded.
No it isn't. You roll the dice weighing values against each other with applied modifiers, or hell, YOU don't even roll the dice, the game does it for you with any given action, and it makes all relevant values for your character be weighed automatically, with the modifiers ensuring that it never boils down to brainless RNG and that values being higher are actually relevant

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9437725
Games like Doom also use dice rolls for its real time combat, and they flow great. The rolled numbers are used for damage (weighed against player armor type and points), as well as weighing what action an enemy will take versus certain timers and behaviors. Hit probability is however dependent on attacks intersecting with a hitbox on the three axes (for the most part), and the only part a diceroll plays there is spread offsets for ranged hitscan attacks.

Morrowind wouldn't need to work like Doom, but I'll concede that there are ways the combat could easily be nicer. However, the early combat jank is easy to get past, focus on your tagged skills and level up a couple of times and it quickly starts to flow better by the virtue of not missing so much.

It is a classic. But it's not underrated, because that would imply it's not actually one of the best selling and well-received video games of all time. It's actually right where it belongs, unless you restrict the viewpoints you ask to a tiny slice of recent history, where you will find that many simply echo poorly-absorbed opinions about the game's difficulty or divergence from the standard Zelda formula that were foisted on them by a generation of "getting angry at video games" style Youtube reviewers.

In reality it is a fantastic game, one that continues to impress me to this day, and one I use as inspiration in my own works. It is one of the great examples of progression of difficulty and "teaching" the player its own mechanics without didactic tutorialism.

Never got into the first one, but I played Mercenary 3 endlessly. Love that game, really kind of influenced me on the whole "vast open lonely world" aesthetic. I'd unironically love to make a new game in this kind of style with just slightly improved flatshaded graphics, some lighting tricks so every polygon isn't quite so indistinguishable from the next..

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>9431367
There's a few things like these with some old games and software, stuff like generating seeds based on date and time and what not. These games will not run (or at least some features won't operate like they should) unless the clock is set to a time period it can deal with.

>>9431672
Diablo is an example of this, where the original .exe will stop being able to generate new seeds for level generation in 2038 (incidentally this is why you can actually write down a time and date and then recall a generated seed for this game by setting your system clock to that).
This is a solved problem with stuff like Devilution X and what not, but it's an example. 4chan itself is another example, what with how filenames are generated and what not, which is why that was updated a while back.

It's not a particularly big problem over all.

>>9431457
I think the difference is that there's going to be way less critical software in use by 2038 which will need to be replaced or updated to address this. Wasn't this problem addressed for a lot of legacy systems along with the Y2K stuff already?

>>9431617
As far as I know, yes.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9437857
There should be less, but as far as industry and such goes, I wouldn't be surprised if there is a lot of systems still using 32-bit backbones that can't deal. I obviously am not all-knowing on the subject, but I can relate this anecdote; Until earlier this year, I worked at a software company, one whose name you wouldn't know, but which supplies essential software to some 200 manufacturers, the top 10 largest global firms in a particular industry. I can also tell you that this very software is built on top of legacy software from the mid-90's and that it is still only able to author as a 32-bit executable. The thing is, correct times and dates are absolutely essential in this system and it won't work correctly without it. Given my experience there, and knowing the experiences too of a few other people who work or have worked at huge companies in other industries, I'll just say that I have little confidence that major companies beyond those on the cutting edge (silicon valley for example) will have their shit together.

This also makes me wonder, will games that require a 32-bit time value someday get a compatibility setting that supplies the game a fake system time value in order to not cause errors with the game?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9430789
Yeah, the masterful thing about that ending is the music. The whole game's music has a lot of range, from bombastic gothic anthem Simon's Theme to somber, moody stuff like the caverns, to quirky, fiendish ballroom music, but all of it, either high tempo or low tempo, sounds pretty dark and oppresive, like you're not ever really at peace, you're still going through an evil eternal night. Then, you defeat Dracula, and the sun rises, and the ending music reflects that. For the first time in the whole game, bright and celestial music plays. Maybe the password screen comes close but that's more like an adequate music for being in a safe place, like a church (in this case, the save screen, which has a church aesthetic). The music is bright, but not quite peaceful, you're still on a quest, just in a safe place. The ending is pure victory of the sun over the night, pure bliss, and very emotional.
What a soundtrack.

Not really. The problem is that everyone thinks procedural generation = less work for more content. This is false. Well-made procedural content takes much more work to test and polish than pre-scripted content. But if you're able and willing to put that work in, you will be richly rewarded. See: Minecraft, Dwarf Fortress, any good roguelike, random maps in Age of Empires 2 or Alpha Centauri, and probably many more I'm forgetting.
